AAE.description: In aviation, above aerodrome level (AAL), or above aerodrome elevation (AAE), denotes that an altitude is given above the nearest aerodrome or airport.

AAIB.full: Air Accident Investigation Branch of the Department of Transportation of the United Kingdom.
AAIB.description: Its role is to investigate air accidents. The letters AAIB also refer to equivalent organizations in Iceland, Singapore and Switzerland, among others. In the United States, the NTSB plays that role.

AB.description: More often used when describing a military airport.

ADAHRS.full: Air data attitude heading reference system

ADI.description: Enhanced artificial horizon with pitch and roll information. It is part of a flight director system.

AIRMET.description: A type of weather advisory regarding certain weather conditions (turbulence, icing, low visiblity) which could pose a threat to only smaller types of aircraft. SIGMET is a more inclusive type of advisory.

ATIS.description: Automatically recorded message transmitted on a particular frequency, containing current weather conditions, QNH setting, active runways, etc., provided at the major airports.

AVGAS.description: Usually followed by the octane rating. Used by piston-engined aircraft.

AVTUR.description: Used by turboprops and jet aircraft.

BRG.description: Horizontal direction to/from a point, expressed in degrees (for example: 000 or 360 is North, 090 is East).

BTV.description: A new feature introduced by Airbus A380

CAA.description: An organization in charge of defining aviation safety standards. The United Kingdom and New Zealand, among others, have organizations with that exact name and role. In the United States, CAA stood for the Civil Aeronautics Administration, a fore-runner of today’s FAA.

CAB.description: Former government agency of the United States responsible, among other things, of investigating air accidents (duties taken over by the NTSB) and controlling which routes the airlines could fly and what fares they could charge (prior to the Airline Deregulation Act).

CAM.description: Part of a cockpit voice recorder

CAS.description: IAS corrected for air density and compressibility.

CAT.description: See CAT I, CAT II, CAT IIIa, CAT IIIb, CAT IIIc

CDI.description: The vertical needle of a VOR indicator which shows the aircraft’s position relative to the selected radial.

COMAT.description: Non-revenue cargo, such as aircraft spare parts.

CRT.description: Television-like screens used in flight decks of new-generation aircraft, replacing the conventional instruments. See also EFIS.

CST.description: CST may also stand for Central Standard Time.

DH.description: Height on a precision approach at which the pilot must have the runway approach lights in sight to continue descent, or if not, initiate a go-around.

DI.description: A gyro instrument which indicates the magnetic heading of an aircraft. The DI, also known as the directional gyro (DG), is free of the turning errors associated with magnetic compasses but is prone to precession (wander) and must be reset against the magnetic compass at intervals.

DLR.full: German Aerospace Center / Deutsches Zentrum fĂĽr Luft- und Raumfahrt e.V.

DME.description: A combination of ground and airborne equipment which gives a continuous slant range distance-from-station readout by measuring time-lapse of a signal transmitted by the aircraft to the station and responded back. DMEs can also provide groundspeed and time-to-station readouts by differentiation.

EFIS.full: Electronic Flight Instrument System, in which multi-function CRT displays replace traditional instruments for providing flight, navigation and aircraft systems information, forming a so-called “glass cockpit”

EGT.description: One of the flight deck’s engine gauges.

ELT.description: Small radio transmitter fixed on the aircraft’s structure, automatically activated by impact or water immersion, transmitting a code enabling SAR satellites or search units equipped with Direction Finders to locate the aircraft’s crash site. Also called ADELT or ELB.

ER.description: Suffix used by some aircraft models (for example: Boeing 767-300ER)

ETOPS.description: Certification given to two-engine aircraft for long overwater flights.

ETSO.full: European Technical Standard Order, issued by EASA; see TSO

EUROCAE.full: European Organization for Civil Aviation Equipment

F/A.description: Also known as Air Hostess in the UK, formerly known as Steward(ess) in North America.

FAA.description: A national aviation authority in charge of defining aviation safety standards in the United States. In some countries, such as the United Kingdom, an equivalent organization is called the CAA.

FBO.description: Supplier of fuel, maintenance, aircraft rental or sale, flight training, etc, at the airport.

FBW.description: Aircraft controls where the pilot’s commands (bank, yaw…) are transmitted to control surfaces electronically or via fiber optics, instead of mechanical linkage. Also called FBL (Fly-By-Light).

FD.full: Flight Disposition Message or Flight Director

FDR.description: One of the so-called “black boxes”. It is actually painted bright orange to be easily identified among aircraft debris, and records various parameters such as altitude, heading, airspeed, engine statistics, etc… It is used to investigate in the case of an accident.

FIDS.description: Real-time flight arrival and departure data for an airport, either as a board inside or near the airport terminal or a virtual version on a website or teletext.

FL.description: Altitude at barometric setting of 1013.2 millibars or 29.92 inches of mercury, expressed in rounds hundreds of feet. This is usual mostly above 18,000 feet. FL350 is 35,000 feet.

FMC.full: flight management computer (part of a FMS)

FN.description: Internal number, for the use of the airline, identifying a particular aircraft within the fleet.

FPM.description: Unit of measure of an aircraft’s rate of climb or descent.

GCA.full: Ground Controlled Approach System or Ground Controlled Approach

GS.description: Vertical guidance, part of an ILS, establishing the safe glidepath to a runway. A standard ILS glideslope is 3 degrees.

HDG.description: The direction in which an aircraft’s nose points in flight in the horizontal plane, expressed in compass degrees (for example: 000 or 360 is North, 090 is East).

HPTACC.full: high pressure turbine active clearance control

HSI.description: A cockpit navigation display, usually part of a flight-director system, which combines navigation and heading.

IAS.description: Airspeed indicated by the Airspeed Indicator, without correction for position error, altitude, or outside air temperature.

ICAS.full: International Council of the Aeronautical Sciences

IDENT.description: When the “Ident” button is activated, an aircraft will briefly appear more distinctly on a radar scope. Used for identification or acknowledgement purposes.

IFATCA.full: International Federation of Air Traffic Controllers Association

IFR.description: Rules prescribed for the operation of aircraft in instrument meteorological conditions

ILS.description: Consists of the localizer, the glideslope and marker radio beacons (Outer, Middle, Inner). It provides horizontal and vertical guidance for the approach.

INS.description: It uses gyroscopes and other electronic tracking systems to detect acceleration and deceleration, and computes an aircraft’s position in latitude and longitude. Its accuracy, however, declines on long flights. Also called IRS, or Inertial Reference System.

IPC.full: illustrated parts catalog (e.g. by Boeing, Airbus)

LATCC.full: London Area and Terminal Control Centre at West Drayton, near London’s Heathrow Airport

LHO.full: Live human organs or fresh human blood

LOC.description: The azimuth guidance portion of an instrument landing system.

LORAN.description: Its range is about 1,200 nm by day, and 2,300 nm by night.

LPTACC.full: low pressure turbine active clearance control

LROPS.description: Certification intended to replace ETOPS as it would include all types of aircraft (not just twin-engine).

METAR.description: Format for shorthand weather information reporting using a standardized set of codes and abbreviations (for example: BKN broken clouds, OVC overcast, CAVOK ceiling and visibility okay, etc.) Acronym possibly comes from the French “Météorologie Aviation Régulière” (routine aviation weather).

MLS.description: A microwave-based instrument approach system intended to replace ILS in the 1990s and claimed to offer a number of advantages such as the ability to fly segmented and curved precision approaches.

MSN.description: Internal number, for the use of the manufacturer, identifying a particular aircraft within the same model.

NDB.description: A medium-frequency navigational aid which transmits non-directional signals, superimposed with a Morse code identifier and received by an aircraft’s ADF.

NIST.full: National Institute of Standards and Technology

NORDO.description: Aircraft without a radio or experiencing a radio failure.

NOTAM.description: Issued by the country’s aviation authority to inform pilots of new or changed aeronautical facilities, services, procedures, or hazards, temporary or permanent.

NTSB.description: A United States government organisation in charge of investigating in the case of an accident. In many countries, an AAIB fulfills that role.

PANS-OPS.full: Procedures For Air Navigation Services - Aircraft Operations

PATWAS.full: Pilot's Automatic Telephone Weather Answering Service

PIREP.description: Weather observations reported by a pilot in flight.

QFE.description: With its sub-scale set to the aerodrome QFE an altimeter will indicate height above that airfield.

QFU.full: magnetic orientation of runway in use

QNE.full: reading in feet on an altimeter set to 1013
QNE.description: 2 millibars (standard pressure) when the aircraft is at aerodrome elevation.

QNH.full: altitude above mean sea level based on local station pressure

QTE.full: true line of position from a direction-finding station

RA.description: When an RA is issued, pilots are expected to respond immediately to the RA unless doing so would jeopardize the safe operation of the flight.

RAAS.description: An electronic detection system that notifies aircraft flight crews on the ground of their position relative to their allocated runway.

RAF.description: Is also used as a prefix for a Royal Air Force base (for example: RAF Mildenhall)

RAS.description: IAS corrected for instrument position error.

RAT.description: A small turbine that is installed in an aircraft and used as an alternate or emergency hydraulic or electrical power source.

RMI.description: A navigation aid which combines DI, VOR and/or ADF display and will indicate bearings to stations, together with aircraft heading.

RNAV.description: A system of radio navigation which permits direct point-to-point off-airways navigation by means of an on-board computer creating phantom VOR/DME transmitters termed waypoints.

RON.description: Aircraft remaining overnight at the airport, either at the gate, remote parking stand or hangar. Airlines take advantage of RONs to perform maintenance, cleaning, etc. on the aircraft.

RVR.description: A horizontal measurement of visibility along a runway.

Roger.description: Also, to roger is to read back and acknowledge an instrction.

SELCAL.description: A high-frequency system enabling air traffic control to alert a particular aircraft, by means of flashing light or aural signal in the cockpit, for receipt of a message without the crew having to maintain a listening watch. Used on long-haul over-ocean airline routes and by intercontinental business jets.

SESMA.full: Special Event Search and Master Analysis

SID.description: A standard IFR departure route enabling air traffic controllers to issue abbreviated clearances and thus speed the flow of traffic.

SIGMET.description: A type of weather advisory regarding severe weather conditions (thunderstorms, turbulence, icing, volcanic ash, etc.) which could pose a threat to all types of aircraft. AIRMET is a less inclusive type of advisory.

SOCAL.full: Southern California TRACON, the busiest approach control in the world, located in San Diego
SOCAL.description: Controls most arrivals for commercial, general aviation, or military airfields in Southern California. Also known as SCT for short.

SODPRO.full: simultaneous opposite direction parallel runway operations

SSR.description: A radar system comprising a ground-based transmitter/receiver which interrogates a compatible unit in the aircraft (the transponder), providing instant radar identification without having to manoeuvre. Assigned four-digit transponder codes are referred to as squawk (see above) codes.

Squawk.full: An assigned code to transmit via a transponder.

TA.description: When a TA is issued, pilots are instructed to initiate a visual search for the traffic causing the TA.

TACAN.description: An ultra-high frequency electronic navigation aid which provides suitably-equipped aircraft with a continuous indication of bearing and distance to the selected Tacan station. The distance element can be received by civilian DME equipment, but otherwise Tacan is principally a military navaid.

TAS.description: Rectified airspeed corrected for altitude and outside air temperature.

TOGA.description: An autopilot setting activating take-off or go-around thrust.

TSB.description: Agency that investigates accidents, in a similar fashion to the NTSB in the United States or an AAIB in other countries.

UHF.description: Radio frequencies in the 300-3,000 MHz band.

UM.description: Underage passenger (typically 5-15 years old) travelling without a parent, guardian or trusted adult. An UM is under the constant supervision of airline staff from the departure gate until he or she is picked up at the arrival airport.

UNICOM.full: privately-operated advisory air-to-ground radio service at uncontrolled airfields, in the United States

UTC.full: Co-ordinated Universal Time, formerly Greenwich Mean Time

V/STOL.full: Vertical and Short Take-Off and Landing

V1.full: decision speed, up to which it should be possible to abort a take-off and stop safely within the remaining runway length
V1.description: After reaching V1 the take-off must be continued.

VA.description: The speed below which abrupt and extreme control movements are possible (though not advised) without exceeding the airframe’s limiting load factors.

VASIS.description: A colored light system providing visual guidance to the glidepath of a runway.

VFE.full: maximum flap extension speed (top of white arc on ASI)

VFR.description: Prescribed for the operation of aircraft in visual meteorological conditions (VMC). VMC is generally defined as 5 miles visibility or more and 1,000 feet vertical and one nautical mile horizontal clearance from cloud, but variations apply to aircraft operating below 3,000 feet AMSL. Special VFR (SVFR) clearances are granted at the discretion of ATC for VFR flight through some controlled airspace where IFR usually apply.

VHF.description: Radio frequencies in the 30-300 MHz band, used for most civil air-to-ground communication.

VMCA.description: The minimum speed at which control of a twin-engined aircraft can be maintained after failure of one engine.

VMO.description: Also Mmo, Mach limit maximum operating speed.

VNE.full: never-exceed speed, ‘redline speed’ denoted by a red radial on an ASI

VNO.description: The maximum structural cruising speed allowable for normal operating conditions (top of green arc on ASI).

VOLMET.full: Meteorological Information For Aircraft in Flight

VOR.description: A radio navigation aid operating in the 108-118 MHz band. A VOR ground station transmits a two-phase directional signal through 360°. the aircraft’s VOR receiver enables a pilot to identify his radial or bearing from/to the ground station. VOR is the most commonly used radio navigation aid in private flying. Increased accuracy is available in DVOR which have replaced some VORs in the UK system. Also VORTAC, combined VOR and TACAN, and VOT (VOR test facility).

VR.full: Rotation speed at which to raise the nose for take-off

VSO.description: in landing configuration with flaps and landing gear down, at sea level, ISA conditions (bottom of white arc on ASI).

VX.full: Best angle of climb speed on all engines

VXSE.full: Best engine-out angle of climb speed

VY.full: Best rate of climb speed on all engines

VYSE.full: Best engine-out rate of climb speed
VYSE.description: ‘blueline speed’ (blue radial on ASIs of light twin aircraft)

WEF.full: With Effect From or Effective From

kts.full: Standard unit of speed in aviation and marine transportation, equivalent to one nautical mile per hour
kts.description: One knot equals 1.1515 mph, and one nautical mile equals 6,080 feet. The word “knot” replaces “nautical miles per hour”, and one should never say for example “60 knots per hour”.
